thread.title: U-M expands tuition-free program to students from families earning up to $125K
thread.title_full: U-M expands tuition-free program to students from families earning up to $125K

author: Dave Boucher, Detroit Free Press
title: U-M expands tuition-free program to students from families earning up to $125K
text:
U-M expands tuition-free program to students from families earning up to $125K Dave Boucher, Detroit Free Press Thu, December 5, 2024 at 11:29 PM UTC 2 min read
More people will soon be able to attend the University of Michigan without paying tuition thanks to the Ann Arbor-based school expanding a program for current and future in-state students.
Starting in the fall, the university's "Go Blue Guarantee" will cover tuition for any student from a family with an annual income of $125,000 and assets of up to $125,000, according to a news release issued Thursday. That's a substantial increase from the previous $75,000 parameter.
“The Go Blue Guarantee breaks down economic barriers and ensures that a world-class education is available to Michigan students from all backgrounds, no matter their family’s economic means,” said U-M President Santa Ono in a statement.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement New students and returning students who fall under the new income criterion are eligible. According to the program website , there is no separate application necessary to be considered for this financial aid at the Ann Arbor campus. New students at the Dearborn and Flint campuses are also eligible.
University of Michigan’s campus in Ann Arbor during dusk on Friday, Nov. 8, 2024. More: U-M researchers seek pancreatic cancer 'Holy Grail': An early detection test
More: Young leaders with Michigan connections make Forbes' 30 under 30 list: Who they are
Since launching the program in 2018, the university says it has covered the tuition of more than 8,000 students.
“As a state university, we have a responsibility to serve the people of Michigan and — given the many pressures of today’s economy — we want to ensure that working-class and middle-class Michiganders can send their children to this great university and benefit from all that it offers,” said Katherine White, chair of the Board of Regents, in a statement.
Advertisement Advertisement The expanded eligibility comes at a time when higher education costs continue to soar. The total cost to attend a four-year college — tuition, fees, room and board, etc. — increased more than 156% from 1963 to 2021, according to the National Center for Education Statistics .
This year, in-state students at the Ann Arbor campus pay about $17,700 for tuition. However, the university says 63% of in-state undergraduate students at the main campus receive grant or scholarship aid.
Expanding the program will cost the university about $8.8 million every year, the university stated.
Reach Dave Boucher at dboucher@freepress.com and on X @Dave_Boucher1.
This article originally appeared on Detroit Free Press: University of Michigan expands tuition-free program
